trans-unit.source: .NET Core Runtime IDentifier (RID) catalog
trans-unit.target: .NET Core Runtime IDentifier (RID) catalog

trans-unit.source: .NET Core Runtime IDentifier (RID) catalog
trans-unit.target: .NET Core Runtime IDentifier (RID) catalog

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: .NET Core Runtime IDentifier (RID) catalog
trans-unit.target: .NET Core Runtime IDentifier (RID) catalog

trans-unit.source: What are RIDs?
trans-unit.target: What are RIDs?

trans-unit.source: RID is short for *Runtime IDentifier*.
trans-unit.target: RID is short for *Runtime IDentifier*.

trans-unit.source: RIDs are used to identify target operating systems where an application or asset (that is, assembly) will run.
trans-unit.target: RIDs are used to identify target operating systems where an application or asset (that is, assembly) will run.

trans-unit.source: They look like this: "ubuntu.14.04-x64", "win7-x64", "osx.10.11-x64".
trans-unit.target: They look like this: "ubuntu.14.04-x64", "win7-x64", "osx.10.11-x64".

trans-unit.source: For the packages with native dependencies, it will designate on which platforms the package can be restored.
trans-unit.target: For the packages with native dependencies, it will designate on which platforms the package can be restored.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that RIDs are really opaque strings.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that RIDs are really opaque strings.

trans-unit.source: This means that they have to match exactly for operations using them to work.
trans-unit.target: This means that they have to match exactly for operations using them to work.

trans-unit.source: As an example, let us consider the case of [Elementary OS](https://elementary.io/), which is a straightforward clone of Ubuntu 14.04.
trans-unit.target: As an example, let us consider the case of [Elementary OS](https://elementary.io/), which is a straightforward clone of Ubuntu 14.04.

trans-unit.source: Although .NET Core and CLI work on top of that version of Ubuntu, if you try to use them on Elementary OS without any modifications, the restore operation for any package will fail.
trans-unit.target: Although .NET Core and CLI work on top of that version of Ubuntu, if you try to use them on Elementary OS without any modifications, the restore operation for any package will fail.

trans-unit.source: This is because we currently (May 3rd, 2016) don't have a RID that designates Elementary OS as a platform.
trans-unit.target: This is because we currently (May 3rd, 2016) don't have a RID that designates Elementary OS as a platform.

trans-unit.source: RIDs that represent concrete operating systems should be of the form: `[os].[version]-[arch]` where:
trans-unit.target: RIDs that represent concrete operating systems should be of the form: `[os].[version]-[arch]` where:

trans-unit.source: is the operating system moniker, for example,
trans-unit.target: is the operating system moniker, for example,

trans-unit.source: is the operating system version in the form of a dot (`.`) separated version number, for example, `10.1511`, accurate enough to reasonably enable assets to target operating system platform APIs represented by that version.
trans-unit.target: is the operating system version in the form of a dot (`.`) separated version number, for example, `10.1511`, accurate enough to reasonably enable assets to target operating system platform APIs represented by that version.

trans-unit.source: This **shouldn't** be marketing versions, as they often represent multiple discrete versions of the operating system with varying platform API surface area, for example,
trans-unit.target: This **shouldn't** be marketing versions, as they often represent multiple discrete versions of the operating system with varying platform API surface area, for example,

trans-unit.source: is the processor architecture, for example, `x86`, `x64`, `arm`, `arm64`, etc.
trans-unit.target: is the processor architecture, for example, `x86`, `x64`, `arm`, `arm64`, etc.

trans-unit.source: The RID graph is defined in a package called `Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms` in a file called `runtime.json` which you can see on the [CoreFX repo](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/pkg/Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms/runtime.json).
trans-unit.target: The RID graph is defined in a package called `Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms` in a file called `runtime.json` which you can see on the [CoreFX repo](https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/pkg/Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms/runtime.json).

trans-unit.source: If you use this file, you will notice that some of the RIDs have an `"#import"` statement in them.
trans-unit.target: If you use this file, you will notice that some of the RIDs have an `"#import"` statement in them.

trans-unit.source: These statements are compatibility statements.
trans-unit.target: These statements are compatibility statements.

trans-unit.source: That means that a RID that has an imported RID in it, can be a target for restoring packages for that RID.
trans-unit.target: That means that a RID that has an imported RID in it, can be a target for restoring packages for that RID.

trans-unit.source: Slightly confusing, but let's look at an example.
trans-unit.target: Slightly confusing, but let's look at an example.

trans-unit.source: Let's take a look at macOS:
trans-unit.target: Let's take a look at macOS:

trans-unit.source: The above RID specifies that `osx.10.11-x64` imports `osx.10.10-x64`.
trans-unit.target: The above RID specifies that `osx.10.11-x64` imports `osx.10.10-x64`.

trans-unit.source: This means that when restoring packages, NuGet will be able to restore packages that specify that they need `osx.10.10-x64` on `osx.10.11-x64`.
trans-unit.target: This means that when restoring packages, NuGet will be able to restore packages that specify that they need `osx.10.10-x64` on `osx.10.11-x64`.

trans-unit.source: A slightly bigger example RID graph:
trans-unit.target: A slightly bigger example RID graph:

trans-unit.source: All RIDs eventually map back to the root `any` RID.
trans-unit.target: All RIDs eventually map back to the root `any` RID.

trans-unit.source: Although they look easy enough to use, there are some special things about RIDs that you have to keep in mind when working with them:
trans-unit.target: Although they look easy enough to use, there are some special things about RIDs that you have to keep in mind when working with them:

trans-unit.source: They are **opaque strings** and should be treated as black boxes
trans-unit.target: They are **opaque strings** and should be treated as black boxes

trans-unit.source: You should not construct RIDs programmatically
trans-unit.target: You should not construct RIDs programmatically

trans-unit.source: You need to use the RIDs that are already defined for the platform and this document shows that
trans-unit.target: You need to use the RIDs that are already defined for the platform and this document shows that

trans-unit.source: The RIDs do need to be specific so don't assume anything from the actual RID value; please consult this document to determine which RID(s) you need for a given platform
trans-unit.target: The RIDs do need to be specific so don't assume anything from the actual RID value; please consult this document to determine which RID(s) you need for a given platform

trans-unit.source: Using RIDs
trans-unit.target: Using RIDs

trans-unit.source: In order to use RIDs, you have to know which RIDs there are.
trans-unit.target: In order to use RIDs, you have to know which RIDs there are.

trans-unit.source: This document lists out the currently supported RIDs in .NET Core.
trans-unit.target: This document lists out the currently supported RIDs in .NET Core.

trans-unit.source: Please be aware that this document is getting updated regularly as new RIDs are added to the platform.
trans-unit.target: Please be aware that this document is getting updated regularly as new RIDs are added to the platform.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to check if new ones are added, please check back here.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to check if new ones are added, please check back here.

trans-unit.source: We are working towards getting this information into a more interactive form.
trans-unit.target: We are working towards getting this information into a more interactive form.

trans-unit.source: When that happens, this page will be updated to point to that tool and/or its usage documentation.
trans-unit.target: When that happens, this page will be updated to point to that tool and/or its usage documentation.
